parse.title: Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen

links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
When little Louis came to stay
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{poem infobox | title=''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen'' | image= | caption= | imageWidth= | imageHeight= | other names=''Lemmincaignen siþaþ tó Oxenaford'',
''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Ford of Oxen'' | written=Late [[October]] of [[1911]] | revised= | published=''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[Wikipedia:Lemminkäinen|Lemminkäinen]] }} '''''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen''''',{{CP|A3}}, p. 1378 (list "A") also known as '''''Lemmincaignen siþaþ tó Oxenaford''''', is a parodic{{CP|Introduction}}, p. xvi poem of a train journey written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] late in [[October]] of [[1911]].{{CP|9}}, pp. 49-53 ==Poem excerpt== ''Runo MDCCCCXI'' ''Argument: Lemminkainen having to depart from Pohja goes again in search of the dragon PufK, who refuses to take him. Honka the roadhop however takes him on his back and puts him down on the banks of the Is-Is. He makes his way to the halls of Kol and there remains.'' :Lo! the lively Kaukomieli :Also known as Lemminkainen :(More familiarly as Kauko) :Got him from the lands of Pohja; :Forth did fare and hasten onwards :Through the gloomy mists of autumn :In the very bluest spirits, :Till he came to where is station'd :In the reek of serpents hundred, :In the noisome smoke of reptiles, :Looming dim and arching upwards :All the vast expanse and cavern'd :Lair of mighty dragon-farers. ==Background== Around a month after writing the poem ''[[The New Lemminkainen]]''{{CP|8}}, pp. 38-48 as a parody of [[Wikipedia:William Forsell Kirby|W.F. Kirby's]] translation of the ''[[Wikipedia:Kalevala|Kalevala]]'',{{CG|C}}, p. 28 (entry "September 1911") [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote a sequel {{webcite |author= [[Christina Scull]] and [[Wayne G. Hammond]]|articleurl= https://www.hammondandscull.com/addenda/guide_by_date2.html|articlename= Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide'' Revised and Enlarged Edition (2017) Vols. 2 & 3: ''Reader's Guide'' · Arranged by Date|dated= 4 September 2025|website= HS|accessed= 1 January 2026|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, note to "p. 680, add entry:" poem entitled ''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen'' or '''''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Ford of Oxen''''' on the same manuscript page of his poetry notebook as the poem ''[[Valedictory|From Iffley]]''. Tolkien described the poem in that manuscript as "a spurious interpolation of the Kálevalá rightly rejected by W.H. [''sic, for W.F.''] Kirby in his translation (A freshman from Birmingham school goes up to Oxford)" and dated it to late{{CP|Chronology}}, entry "Late October 1911" [[October]] of [[1911]]. After the end of the poem, Tolkien wrote:{{Blockquote|Having promis'd another production I felt I must send one. I do (with all apologies). You may consign it to the wagger-pagger-tagger (Oxonese [Oxford student slang] for waste paper basket) if you like. [signed] R.}} In a list of poems marked "''[[Ungefeged inne]]''" that were probably "contemporary with" another list labeled "[[Attempts at Verse]]", Tolkien included ''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen'' and named it ''Lemmincaignen siþaþ tó Oxenaford'' in [[Old English]]. In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was published for the first time as entry 9 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''. In their commentary, [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] suggest that Tolkien's note at the end was probably an address to "one of his friends from King Edward's School". In a note to Runo MDCCCCXI, Hammond and Scull explain that while these roman numerals imply that the poem is only "part of an enormously longer" work, it simply translates "to the date of composition, 1911".{{CP|9}}, note "Title:" In a note to lines 54-6,{{CP|9}}, note "54-6:" Hammond and Scull point out that Tolkien used similar imagery in ''[[Valedictory|From Iffley]]'', which was written around the same time as ''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen''.{{CP|10}}, p. 56 Tolkien would eventually use such imagery again in [[When little Louis came to stay|an unnamed epistolary poem]] {{webcite |author= |articleurl= https://explore.library.leeds.ac.uk/special-collections-explore/376727/poem_by_j_r_r_tolkien_sent_to_eric_and_ida_gord|articlename= Poem by J. R. R. Tolkien sent to Eric and Ida Gordon|dated= 18 February 1952|website= [https://library.leeds.ac.uk/ University of Leeds library]|accessed= 1 January 2026|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}} that he would later write to [[Eric Valentine Gordon]] and [[Ida Lilian Gordon]]{{webcite |author= [[Christina Scull]] and [[Wayne G. Hammond]]|articleurl= https://www.hammondandscull.com/addenda/chronology_by_date.html|articlename= Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide'' (2006) Vol. 1: Chronology · Arranged by Date|dated= 31 March 2015|website= HS|accessed= 1 January 2026|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, note to "pp. 841-73"{{webcite |author= [[Christina Scull]] and [[Wayne G. Hammond]]|articleurl= https://www.hammondandscull.com/addenda/guide_by_date.html|articlename= Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide'' (2006) Vol. 2: Reader's Guide · Arranged by Date|dated= 31 March 2015|website= HS|accessed= 1 January 2026|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, note to "'''pp. 515-17''', entry for '''Libraries and archives''', subsection 'Other Libraries and Archives':"{{CG|2RGI}}, Libraries and archives, Other Libraries and Archives: University of Leeds, pp. 515-7.{{CP|143}}, p. 1112 ==Inspiration== In their commentary in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'', Hammond and Scull suggest that, since the poem is about "a journey to Oxford" and was written around when Tolkien "went up to university as a freshman", it is likely that Tolkien wrote ''Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen'' as an autobiographical parody of Tolkien's own journey, sacrificing "history for comedy". In a note to the Argument, Hammond and Scull pointed out that the names Pohja, Is-Is, and the halls of Kol are stand-ins for [[Wikipedia:Birmingham|Birmingham]] (north of Oxford), [[Wikipedia:The Isis|the Isis]] (the part of the [[Wikipedia:Thames|Thames]] running through [[Wikipedia:Oxfordshire|Oxford]]), and "the college (kol-lege) halls of the [[University of Oxford|University]]" respectively.{{CP|9}}, note "Argument:" While Hammond and Scull admitted they were unable "to explain the capital letter at the end" of PufK, they speculate that, without the "K", the name refers to Puffpuff, the train from ''[[The New Lemminkainen]]'', the earlier Lemminkainen poem. {{References}} {{Poems}} [[Category:Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien]]
